title: Measuring the Ocean
caption: The Ocean Observatories Initiative (OOI) has hundreds of instruments collecting data every minute of every day from seven locations (arrays) throughout the Pacific and Atlantic Oceans. Some of the data in this activity were collected from the Cabled Axial Seamount location in the Temperate Pacific Ocean (red box).

title: Where are the Instruments in the Water?
caption: The Cabled Axial Seamount location is in the ocean off of Oregon at the most active marine volcano on the Juan de Fuca Ridge, which has erupted multiple times since 1998. The collection of instruments is the most advanced underwater volcano observatory in the ocean around the world.

title: What it Looks Like Under the Water
caption: This drawing represents where the different OOI instruments are attached to cables along the seafloor at the Cabled Axial Seamount. The data in this activity collected after 2012 were recorded by instruments in the Central Caldera, Eastern Caldera, and International District sites (red boxes).

title: What Collects the Seismic Data?
caption: Broadband Ocean Bottom Seismometers (BOBS) provide data of seafloor movement along plate boundaries and from magma movement at underwater volcanoes. Then scientists can calculate the magnitude and depth of the earthquakes. The OOI uses a Guralp model CMG-1T/5T as its BOBS, seen here ready to be put into the ocean.

title: Where does this data come from?
caption: Data for this activity were provided by Dr. Bill Chadwick (Oregon State University and NOAA/PMEL) and Dr. Scott Nooner (University of North Carolina at WIlmington) who collected and analyzed these data over many years, projects, funding sources, and cruises. They maintain a blog of their research findings.
